abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: Participants in epidemiological and genetic studies are rarely truly random samples of the populations they are intended to represent, and both known and unknown factors can influence participation in a study (also known as selection into a study). The circumstances in which selection causes bias in an instrumental variable (IV) analysis are not well understood. We use directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) to depict assumptions about the selection mechanism (i.e., the factors affecting selection into the study), and show how DAGs can be used to determine when a two stage least squares (2SLS) IV analysis is biased by selection. For a range of selection mechanisms we explain the structure of the selection bias and, via simulations, we illustrate the potential bias caused by selection in an IV analysis. We show that selection can result in a biased 2SLS estimate of the causal exposure effect, substantial undercoverage of its confidence interval, and the chance of reaching an incorrect conclusion about the causal exposure effect. We consider whether the bias caused by selection differ according to different instrument strengths, between a linear and nonlinear exposure-instrument association, and for a causal and non-causal exposure effect. In addition, we present the results of a real data example where nonrandom selection into the study was suspected. We conclude that selection bias can have a major effect on an IV analysis and that statistical methods for estimating causal effects using data from nonrandom samples are needed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The main aim of many epidemiological studies is to estimate the causal effect of an exposure (or treatment) on an outcome; that is, the effect on the outcome of changing the exposure. A major challenge for observational studies is unmeasured confounding of the outcome and exposure but standard analyses, such as ordinary least squares regression, make the untestable assumption that there is no unmeasured confounding. One solution is an instrumental variable (IV) analysis which can control for unmeasured confounders. An IV analysis requires variable, known as the instrument, to satisfy three assumptions: (1) the instrument is associated with the exposure, (2) the instrument only causes the outcome to change via its impact on the exposure, and (3) there is no confounding between the instrument and the outcome (1-3). Based on the observed data, the first IV assumption can be tested, but the latter two IV assumptions are untestable.

As with any statistical analysis, to obtain a valid inference about the causal exposure effect the participants of the analysed data should be a representative sample of the population under study. There are several reasons why the participants of the analysed data (i.e., our selected sample) may not be a representative sample, including: nonrandom sampling, nonrandom participant refusal, loss to follow-up, subgroups analysis, and missing data (i.e., restricting the analysis to those participants with complete data). In all of these cases there may be both known and unknown factors that influence the “selection” of participants for analysis. Following Hernán and Robins (4), we consider selection bias to be distinct from confounding; that is, for an exposure-outcome association, selection bias is due to conditioning on common effects (or common causes) of the outcome and the exposure, whilst confounding is due to the presence of common causes of the outcome and exposure. We consider our IV estimate of the causal exposure effect, based on our selected sample for analysis, to be biased by selection when it systematically differs to the value of the causal exposure effect in the population of interest (5),.

Although there is extensive literature on IV analysis, there is relatively limited information on the effects of selection. Recent exceptions include examples where selection depends on the: exposure (6), instrument plus measured and unmeasured confounders (of the outcome-exposure association) (7), exposure and measured variable (which causes the outcome) (8), missing values of measured covariates (9, 10), and unmeasured confounder plus measured covariates (11). Typically, an IV analysis ignores how participants were selected for analysis, and so implicitly assumes that the sample selected for analysis are representative of the population. However, ignoring the selection process in an IV analysis can lead to bias (6, 8). In addition to the limited information on the consequences of nonrandom selection, the structure of the selection bias is not always fully understood. For example, Canan et al (8) describe an IV analysis where the outcome is associated with a measured variable and selection depends on the exposure and the measured variable. The authors state that in the selected sample the outcome-instrument association is confounded by the measured variable. Although correct, in this example, selection also results in unmeasured confounding of the outcome-instrument association; hence adjusting for the measured variable would not eliminate selection bias.

In this paper, we review the circumstances in which an IV analysis is biased by selection for eight examples of selection which can occur in practice. We use directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) to jointly depict the IV analysis and selection process, and show how DAGs can be used to determine when selection violates the IV assumptions. Also, we illustrate the consequences of ignoring selection in an IV analysis via simulations. In Section 2, we introduce our IV analysis, and describe the structure of the selection bias for the eight examples of selection considered. Section 3 presents our simulation study, and section 4 presents the results of our data example. We conclude with a general discussion in Section 5.

sec.title: When does selection lead to bias?
sec.p: Whether an IV analysis is biased by selection depends on the causes of selection and the causal relationships among the variables of the IV analysis. We begin with a description of our IV analysis, and then discuss, for a range of examples of selection, whether our analysis would be biased by selection.

sec.title: Description of our IV analysis
sec.p: We want to estimate the effect of a continuous exposure X on a continuous outcome Y and we shall denote this causal exposure effect by βX. The Y - X association is confounded by unmeasured variables U and measured variables C. In the full sample (i.e., the selected and unselected participants), the instrument Z satisfies the three core assumptions of an IV analysis (without conditioning on C). Figure 1a is a directed acyclic graph (DAG) showing the causal relationships among these variables.

caption.p: Directed acyclic graphs of an instrumental variable analysis under no selection and eight different selection mechanisms.

sec.p:
To identify βX we assume homogeneous exposure effects; that is, βX is the same for all individuals (12). We estimate βX using the two stage least squares (2SLS) method (13) and denote its 2SLS estimate by . In the first stage of 2SLS, X is regressed on Z to give fitted values In the second stage, the regression coefficient of Y on fitted values is the 2SLS estimate, When Z is a single instrument, is equivalently estimated using the ratio of coefficients method (14, 15)
where the numerator, is the estimated coefficient from the regression of Y on Z, and the denominator, is the estimated coefficient from the regression of X on Z. We also estimate the causal exposure effect conditional on (or adjusted for) measured confounders C, and denote this conditional 2SLS estimate by .

sec.title: Selection mechanisms
sec.p: Whether IV estimate , is biased by selection depends on the reasons for selection, which we shall call the “selection mechanism”. Figures 1b to 1i depict 8 different selection mechanisms, where S is a binary variable indicating whether a participant is selected or not selected. Restricting the analysis to the selected sample implies conditioning on S which is represented by a box around S. Among the selection mechanisms we consider, is biased by selection when selection implies conditioning on a collider in a non-causal pathway between Z and Y via C or U, which results in violating the IV assumption that there is no confounding between Z and Y (16, 17). We can ignore confounding of the X - Z association because outcome Y is continuous, and so is consistently estimated even when the first stage regression (X on Z) is misspecified (18).

Figure 1b depicts selection mechanism “completely at random”, where selection does not depend on any observed or unobserved data, and so the selected participants are a representative sample of the unselected participants. For the remaining selection mechanisms, there are systematic differences between the selected and unselected participants. Below, we explain when selection does and does not bias , and table 1 provides a summary of this discussion. Unless otherwise stated, whether is biased by selection equally applies when X does and does not cause Y (i.e., true causal effect is not null and null). Also note, in our example all variables are measured without error since our concern is selection bias and not measurement bias. However, whether is biased by selection equally applies when selection depends on the variables measured with error (4).

caption.p: Potential bias of the two stage least squares (2SLS) estimate of the casual exposure effect, , and the corresponding 2SLS estimate conditional on , according to different selection mechanisms.

sec.p: When selection is completely at random (Figure 1b) or selection depends on Z (Figure 1c), is not biased by selection. The Y - Z association is not confounded in the selected sample because all non-causal pathways between Z and Y (i.e., via C and U) remain blocked by colliders X and Y.

When selection depends on Z + C (i.e., Z and C; Figure 1d), is biased by selection because conditioning on S opens the non-causal pathway , resulting in confounding of Y - Z by C. However, conditioning on C re-blocks this pathway, thus eliminating the selection bias. Therefore, whilst is biased by selection the 2SLS estimate conditional on , is not biased by selection. We note one exception. Suppose selection depended on Z + C but we C, have measured confounder C with error, denoted by C* (DAG not shown). Conditioning on this mismeasured variable C* would not block the non-causal pathway between Z and Y via S and C, and so selection bias would not be eliminated. Furthermore, conditioning on C* would result in confounding the Y - Z association by the measurement error of C, known as “residual confounding”. However, if selection depended on Z plus the mismeasured variable C* then conditioning on C* would now block the non-causal pathway between Z and Y via S and C, thus eliminating the selection bias, and it would not induce residual confounding; hence the 2SLS estimate conditional on C* would be unbiased.

When selection depends on X, X + Z, X + C or X + Y (Figures 1e, 1f, 1g and 1h respectively), is biased by selection due to confounding of the Y - Z association by C and U. Because S is a descendant of X, conditioning on S unblocks any pathways which include X as a collider; that is, the non-causal pathway between Z and Y via , and the non-causal pathway via Note, conditioning on a descendant of X is not the same as directly conditioning on X (such as in the regression of Y on X). Because we are not directly conditioning on X, pathways between Z and Y which include X as a partial mediator are not closed by selection. For selection mechanisms X + Z and X + C there are also non-causal pathways between Z and Y via S and C or U, which are unblocked by conditioning on S; for example, for mechanism X + C.

Selection depending on Y (Figure 1i) has the special property that is only biased by selection when X causes Y because all sources of selection bias, for this mechanism, require an edge between X and Y. When X causes Y, S is a descendant of X and so conditioning on S unblocks any non-causal pathway that includes collider X (i.e., , and ,); thus, the Y - Z association is confounded by C and U in the selected sample. When X does not cause Y, X is not a descendant of S and so these non-causal pathways remain blocked by collider X. Consequently, the Y - Z association remains unconfounded in the selected sample, and , is not biased by selection.

For selection mechanisms X, X + C, X + Z, X + Y, and Y, estimating the causal exposure effect conditional on C, , reduces the magnitude of the selection bias because conditioning on C eliminates confounding by C. However, , remains biased by selection because of unmeasured confounding of the Y - Z association.

sec.p:

sec.title: Results
sec.p: When there was no selection (i.e., all 20, 000 observations were analysed), was unbiased and CI coverage was nominal for all simulation settings (causal and non-causal exposure effect, linear and nonlinear X - Z association, and strong and moderate instrument). (Results available on request). The F-statistics of X on Z were large, in part, due to the large sample size of 20, 000 observations: median F-statistic of 946 (interquartile range (IQR) 84) for linear X - Z and moderate instrument, 12784 (IQR 386) for linear X - Z and strong instrument, 936 (IQR 146) for nonlinear X - Z and moderate instrument, and 12958 (IQR 470) for nonlinear X - Z and strong instrument.

Table 2 presents the results of the simulation study according to the moderate and strong instrument, when the true causal exposure effect was 1, and the X - Z association was linear. When selection was completely at random or depended on Z only, was unbiased and CI coverage was nominal. Because this finding applied to all simulation settings we shall not discuss these two selection mechanisms further. For the remaining selection mechanisms, was negatively biased with poor (88%) to severe (0%) CI undercoverage. For selection mechanisms Z + C and X + Z the level of bias increased with decreasing instrument strength: in comparison to the strong instrument (), the level of bias was 3 to 4 times larger for the moderate instrument () and close to double for instrument strength (results available on request). When selection did not depend on Z, there were only small differences in the level of bias between the instrument strengths. For all selection mechanisms, decreasing the instrument strength resulted in larger standard errors and higher CI coverage: in comparison to the strong instrument, the mean standard errors were 3 to 4 times larger for the moderate instrument, and close to double for instrument strength (results available on request). The standard errors of were neither underestimated nor overestimated (results of the relative error statistic not shown). Therefore, CI undercoverage was only due to a biased 2SLS estimate.

Monte Carlo errors in brackets, except for partial .

sec.p: Despite a biased 2SLS estimate and poor CI coverage, 100% of the CIs showed evidence of a positive exposure effect for all simulation settings where the true casual effect was 1. This was in part due to the large sample size and relatively large effect size of 1 (i.e., relatively far from 0). When we lowered the effect size to 0.25, and used the moderate instrument strength, a small (1%) to large percentage (76%) of the CIs showed evidence of a null exposure effect (i.e., included the null), where the percentage of CIs including the null effect increased with larger selection bias. (Results available on request).

In general, the results for a nonlinear X-Z association (Supplementary Table S3) follow the same pattern noted for a linear X - Z association. However, certain differences were noted between a linear and nonlinear X - Z association. For the moderate instrument the level of bias was slightly higher for nonlinear X - Z when selection depended on Z + C, whilst for the remaining selection mechanisms it was slightly lower for nonlinear X - Z. To understand further we shall compare the effect of a nonlinear X - Z association on selection mechanisms Z + C and X for the moderate instrument. For selection mechanism Z + C, a nonlinear X - Z association resulted in greater selection bias (i.e., stronger confounding of Y - Z by C) because the C - Y association was stronger for nonlinear X - Z. Note, the Z - C association was comparable between linear and nonlinear X - Z because its magnitude depended on quantities (i.e., magnitudes of the Z - S and C - S associations, and the distribution of S (16)) that were independent of X. For selection mechanism X, a nonlinear X - Z association resulted in lower selection bias (i.e., weaker confounding of Y - Z confounding by C and U) because the induced Z - C and Z - U associations were noticeably weaker when X - Z was nonlinear. The strength of these induced associations depended on the strengths of the Z - X, X - C and X - U associations, and the distribution of X. Whilst the former were similar between linear and nonlinear X - Z, the distribution of X differed: for nonlinear X - Z, the spread of the distribution was much wider and it was more positively skewed. The effect of this change in the distribution of X was a larger proportion of selected observations with a positive value of X, and the induced Z - C and Z - U associations were weak in those with a positive value of X. Consequently, among all selected values of X these induced associations were weak. When the instrument was strong, the levels of selection bias were more comparable between linear and nonlinear X - Z because the nonlinearity had less of an effect on features, such as the C - Y association and the distribution of X, that determined the magnitude of the selection bias.

For the moderate and strong instruments, the standard errors of were smaller for nonlinear X - Z compared to linear X - Z, with larger differences for the moderate instrument. Note, the asymptotic variance is , where is the estimate of the variance of the residuals from the second stage regression of 2SLS (i.e., Y on fitted values ), and SSTX is the total sum of squares for X (21). The smaller standard errors for nonlinear X - Z were primarily due to a substantial increase in (results not shown). When the level of bias was comparable between linear and nonlinear X - Z, CI coverages were poorer for nonlinear X - Z due to smaller standard errors. However, in situations where a nonlinear X - Z lowered the level of bias (e.g., when the instrument was moderate and selection depended on X only) then CI coverages were substantially higher, despite smaller standard errors.

In keeping with our discussion in Section 2.2, selection depending on Y did not bias when the causal exposure effect was null (Supplementary Table S4 for linear X - Z and Supplementary Table S5 for nonlinear X - Z). For the remaining selection mechanisms, the results for a causal and non-causal exposure effect were very similar.

Since selecting on Z + C resulted in confounding Y - Z by C only, then estimating the causal exposure effect conditional on C eliminated the selection bias; that is, was unbiased and CI coverage was nominal (Supplementary Table S6). For the remaining mechanisms, whilst conditioning on C reduced the level of selection bias it did not eliminate all of the bias because the Y - Z association was also confounded by U.

sec.title: Data example
sec.p: We now consider an IV analysis examining the causal effect of education on the decision to smoke using data from the UK Biobank study (22) where nonrandom selection of participants into the analysis dataset was suspected. Full details of the IV analysis are provided in (23).

Smoking is still a major avoidable risk factor for ill health and premature mortality worldwide (24). Higher educational achievement predicts lower levels of smoking uptake and, among those who started smoking, higher levels of quitting smoking (25, 26). However, we do not know whether this is due to a causal effect of education on the decision to smoke, or if this association is due to unmeasured confounding factors. To counteract the possible effects of unmeasured confounding an IV analysis was conducted where the instrument was a policy reform, introduced on 1st September 1972, which raised the school leaving age from 15 to 16 years. Individuals who turned 15 before this date could leave school at age 15 whilst younger individuals, who turned 15 after 1st September 1972, had to remain in school at least until age 16. This example uses the policy reform (often referred to as ROS1A, Raising of School 1eaving Age) as an instrument for time spent in education. The ROS1A has been used as an instrument in previous examples (23, 27, 28) and for the purposes of this example we assume that the instrument is valid. Note, the example is intended to demonstrate the impact of sample selection on linear regression and IV analyses, and not as a comprehensive analysis of the effect of education on smoking in adult life.

The UK Biobank study is a sample of 502, 644 individuals who attended 23 study clinics across the UK, and did not subsequently withdraw from the study, between 2006 and 2010 (22). At the time of the study the invited participants were aged between 40 and 69 years old and so would have turned age 15 some time between 1952 and 1985. The study achieved a response rate of 5.5% after inviting 9.2 million individuals to participate in the study (29). Higher levels of educational achievement predicted attendance at a study clinic, and so sampling by UK Biobank (29). Therefore, it is plausibe that study participants were nonrandomly selected depending on the exposure of interest, educational attainment. As discussed in Section 2.2 and shown in Section 3.2, selection depending on the exposure can bias an IV analysis. We considered it reasonable to assume that the sampling of study participants by UK Biobank was completely at random, and so this selection process was ignored. Because the ROS1A only affected England and Wales, we restricted our sample to those participants born in England or Wales. In addition, among those born in England or Wales, we only included participants who answered questions about the age at which they left school or their highest level of qualification. For the purposes of this example we have assumed that there were no systematic differences between the UK Biobank participants selected for analysis (i.e., born in England or Wales and information on the exposure) and those UK Biobank participants not selected for analysis (i.e., born outside of England and Wales, or no information on the exposure) with respect to the exposure, outcome, or any confounders of the exposure-outcome association. Under this assumption the selection process would not bias our analysis; therefore, we have ignored selection on place of birth and whether information on the exposure was observed or missing.

Using the notation of Section 2.1, the outcome Y was a binary variable, equal to one if the participant had ever smoked (i.e., includes ex-smokers and current smokers), and equal to zero if the participant had never smoked. We also considered a second outcome which was also a binary variable, equal to one if, at the time of the study clinic, the participant was a current smoker, and equal to zero if the participant did not smoke at that time (i.e., included ex-smokers and never smokers). Separate analyses were performed on each outcome using the same exposure and instrument. The exposure X was a binary variable, equal to one if the participant had left school age 16 or older, and equal to zero otherwise. The instrument, Z, was also a binary variable, equal to one if the participant turned 15 before the policy reform was introduced, and equal to zero otherwise. There were no measured confounders, C, of the exposure-outcome association but we suspect there were unmeasured confounders, U. Although the validity of the instrument did not require conditioning on any measured variables, following Clark and Royer (27) we have adjusted for sex and month of birth.

We conducted the IV analysis using the linear probability model. This model is a form of 2SLS estimation in which the outcome, exposure and instrument are binary, and the causal exposure effect is on the risk difference scale (30). For a single binary instrument the causal exposure effect estimated under the linear probability model can be expressed as in equation 1, where the numerator, , and denominator, , are linear regression coefficients. We note, for both of these linear regressions, Y given Z and X given Z, the dependent variable is binary which may produce predicted values outside of the 0 to 1 range (31). Robust standard errors were calculated to account for assumptions about homogeneous exposure effects and the outcome distributions. For comparison, we also considered the equivalent standard analysis; that is, the linear regression of Y on X (e.g., current smoking on “left school age 16 or older”), also with robust standard errors. Although the standard analysis may be biased by unmeasured confounding of the exposure-outcome association, we know from the missing data literature (e.g., (32)) that the results of the standard analysis are not biased by selection on the exposure, X.

A weighted IV analysis, in which the weights to try to make the selected participants representative of all invited participants, (e.g., (7)) can account for unmeasured confounding and selection bias. We used the weighting method known as inverse probability weighting (33). Under the assumption that selection only depended on the exposure X, the weights were the inverse of the conditional probabilities of selection given the exposure. The selected participants who left school age 15 were weighted by 34.29, and the selected participants who left school age 16 or older were weighted by 12.37 (weights rounded to 2 decimal places). So, those participants suspected to be under-represented in the selected sample (i.e., left school age 15) contributed more to the analysis than those suspected to be over-represented in the selected sample (i.e. left school age 16 or older). For comparison, we carried out a weighted linear regression analysis using the same weights. (See the supplementary material for information on the calculation of the weights.) For both weighted analyses the weights were treated as known (i.e., uncertainty in the estimated weights were ignored), which generally leads to conservative inference (33).

Table 3 presents the results for the exposure effect estimated using unweighted and weighted versions of the linear regression and IV analyses. For the IV analysis there were noticeable differences between the unweighted and weighted analyses. For outcome ever smoker, the weighted IV estimate was more than double that of the unweighted IV estimate, although there was some overlap between the corresponding 95% confidence intervals. Both analyses suggested staying in school at least one extra year (i.e., leaving at age 16 or older) decreased the likelihood of being an ever smoker compared to those who left school at age 15, although the confidence interval for the unweighted analysis included all 3 possible effects: risk decrease, no effect, and risk increase. For outcome current smoker, the results of the unweighted IV analysis suggested staying in school at least one extra year increased the likelihood of being a current smoker compared to those who left school at age 15, whilst the results of the weighted IV suggested the opposite effect. Similarly, the confidence interval for the unweighted analysis included all 3 possible effects. We note, weighting also improved efficiency resulting in narrower confidence intervals.

caption.p: Risk difference %, of ever smoker or current smoker, for leaving school at age 16 or older compared to leaving school at age 15 using unweighted and weighted versions of linear regression and instrumental variable (IV) analysis. 95% confidence intervals displayed within brackets.

sec.p: As expected, the unweighted and weighted results of the linear regression analyses were identical. Weighting under the assumption of selection depending on the exposure will not affect the estimated value because selection under this mechanism does not bias the exposure effect estimate of a linear regression.

Comparing the (unweighted or weighted) linear regression results to the weighted IV, both of which should not be biased by selection on the exposure. Although the direction of the exposure effects were the same, the linear regression exposure effect estimates were about 2 to 3 times larger than those of the weighted IV, and there was no overlap in the 95% confidence intervals. Note, the confidence intervals of the IV analyses were noticeably wider than those of the linear regression analyses because standard errors of a 2SLS estimate are always larger than those of an OLS estimate (21).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: For eight different selection mechanisms, we have explained the structure of the selection bias and showed how DAGs can be used to determine if selection violates any of the IV assumptions. Using simulations, we then illustrated the effects of the 8 selection mechanisms on the 2SLS estimate of the causal exposure effect. For a causal and null exposure effect, the 2SLS estimate was not biased when the selected sample was representative of the population under study or when selection depended on the instrument only. However, it was biased when selection depended on the instrument plus measured confounder, or depended (in part or entirely) on the exposure, or depended on the outcome plus exposure. A special case was selection depending on the outcome only, where the 2SLS estimate was only biased when X truly caused Y. Decreasing the instrument strength resulted in an increase in the level of bias for selection mechanisms partly depending on the instrument, but had little effect on the other selection mechanisms. However, weakening the instrument increased the standard errors for all selection mechanisms. Whilst the larger standard errors improved CI coverage when the 2SLS estimate was biased, there was still substantial CI undercoverage. Estimating the conditional 2SLS estimate eliminated selection bias when caused by measured confounding, but only reduced the level of bias when selection resulted in measured and unmeasured confounding. Changing the exposure-instrument association from linear to nonlinear (i.e., cubic) reduced the size of the standard errors, but its effect on bias depended on the structure of the selection bias.

Similarly to our study, other authors have used DAGs to illustrate when the instrument-outcome association becomes confounded due to selection (6-8). However, two of these papers (7, 8) only discuss selection causing confounding by either measured or unmeasured variables when in fact there was confounding by both types of variables. In keeping with the results of our simulation study, non-trivial levels of selection bias were demonstrated via simulations (6, 8). However, these papers only considered a single selection mechanism, and did not investigate if the effects of selection differed according to a null and non-null causal exposure effects, or a linear and nonlinear exposure-instrument association. Differently from our study, others have examined the effects of selection when it depends on unmeasured or partially observed data (e.g., (9-11)).

There is evidence that nonrandom selection can occur in practice with large differences in the characteristics of the selected and unselected participants (i.e., indicating a strong selection mechanism). For example, consider selection into the UK Biobank study. The percentage of subjects who owned their property outright was 56.7% in the UK Biobank study (i.e., the selected sample) and 40.6% in the 2001 UK census (i.e., the study population) (29). Since recruitment to the UK Biobank study was rare we shall assume that the percentage of subjects who owned their property outright was 40.6% in those who declined to participate in the UK Biobank study (i.e., the not selected sample). Therefore, using this approximation and the symmetry property of the odds ratio, the odds of selection among outright property owners was almost double that of those who were not outright property owners. Another example is selection into the Avon 1ongitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC) study (34). Using similar calculations, where the study population is the Avon population and not the whole of the UK, the odds of selection among households with a car was almost double the odds of section among households without a car.

In our simulation study the direction of the selection bias was negative for a causal and non-causal exposure effect. However, we would have obtained positive bias if we had set the direction of the exposure’s associations with the confounders to be in the opposite direction to that of the outcome’s associations with the confounders; that is, set the exposure to be positively associated with the confounders and the outcome to be negatively associated with the confounders, or vice versa. Also, we note that the magnitude of the selection bias depends on several features of the data (e.g., distribution of the exposure, strength of the instrument-exposure, magnitude of the confounder-exposure and confounder-outcome associations) (6), as well as the strength of the selection mechanism (e.g., how strongly the exposure is associated with being selected). Regarding testing for the existence of a causal exposure effect, the sample size and true effect size (i.e., distance from the null) also affect how likely the results will lead to an incorrect conclusion.

Our simulation study has several limitations. First, whilst we considered eight plausible selection mechanisms, it was not possible to investigate all possible selection mechanisms even for a single IV analysis example. Second, in practice an IV analysis may use weaker instruments than we considered. We chose a sample size that was typical of an IV analysis so that even for an partial of 0.045 the instrument woulnot be considered weak. However, for the purposes of our study, we wanted to ensure that any bias was attributable only to selection and not to weak instrument bias (15). Third, our simulation study was designed to show the effects of different selection mechanisms on an IV analysis and not an exhaustive investigation of the magnitudes of selection bias that could occur in practice. Such an investigation would be best limited to a single selection mechanism where different values for the parameters, of the data and selection models, that can affect the magnitude of selection bias are considered, and choosing parameters values based on real IV analyses. Fourth, our use of non-parametric DAGs, to determine if selection would violate one of the core IV assumptions, are not suitable for all types of selection mechanisms (e.g., selection depending on the parameteri-:ation of the IV analysis (5)). However, for non-parametric selection mechanisms, DAGs are easier to understand than mathematical statements about the validity of an IV analysis under selection.

For some selection mechanisms, selection biases the 2SLS estimate but not the ordinary least squares estimate; for example, when selection depends on the exposure. Although, unlike the IV estimate, the ordinary least squares estimate may be biased by confounding. In such cases the magnitude of the selection bias (for the 2SLS estimate) may exceed the bias due to confounding of the ordinary least squares estimate. Ideally, estimation of the causal exposure effect should correctly account for unmeasured confounding and nonrandom selection. Inverse probability weighting (8) and multiple imputation (10) have been used to appropriately account for selection in an IV analysis. Commercially available implementations of these methods usually assume the chance of selection depends on measured variables that are fully observed for all participants of the full sample. When selection depends on unmeasured variables or partially observed variables, MI and IPW may not fully account for selection and give a biased 2SLS estimate (7, 10). There are a limited number of approaches that try to account for selection depending on unmeasured or partially observed data (7, 9, 10), but they tend to be less straightforward, make untestable assumptions or are specific to a particular type of IV analysis.

With individual level data on the selected and unselected participants, an IV analyst can investigate possible factors that influence selection. However, this is not possible when the IV analyst only has summary level data. Providers of summary level data should indicate the chance that the summary level data is based on a nonrandom sample of the population of interest, and posit possible selection mechanisms. Where possible, these providers could generate summary level data accounting for nonrandom selection (e.g., summary level data from a weighted analysis, or summary level data adjusted for known factors associated with selection). Two sample IV analyses tend to be conducted using summary level data, and these analyses are further complicated because there are two opportunities for nonrandom selection to occur, and possibly two different selection mechanisms to take into account. Future work could develop doubly robust methods to account for selection, which would give valid results even when one of the samples has been incorrectly adjusted for selection.

There is current debate regarding representativeness of a study’s results and findings to populations that differ from the study population (e.g., (35)). However, nonrandom selection is concerned with the accuracy of a study’s results for the study population; that is, whether the selected sample is unrepresentative of the study population leading to study results that systematically differ from their true values in the study population. Therefore, we consider nonrandom selection to be a separate issue from generalisability to other populations.

In summary, ignoring how participants are selected for analysis can result in a biased 2SLS estimate, substantial CI undercoverage, and lead to an incorrect conclusion that an exposure is not causal. This limitation should be noted in guidelines for IV analyses. DAGs can be used to assess if the IV analysis may be biased by the assumed selection mechanism. Future work could provide researchers guidance on statistical methods, diagnostic tools and sensitivity analyses for estimating causal effects from nonrandom samples.

sec.title: Calculation of the weights
sec.p: In our data example, Section 4, we conducted a weighted IV analysis and a weighted standard analysis. To calculate the weights we have assumed that the exposure (an extra year of compulsory education) was the only factor causing participation into Biobank. Also, we have assumed that there was no effect of cigarette smoking on selection into UK Biobank (although Fry et al, (29), would suggest otherwise). This example is for illustrative purposes only; in practice a thorough investigation of the factors likely to affect selection would be necessary.

Under the assumption that selection S only depended on the exposure X, the weights were the inverse of the conditional probabilities of selection given the exposure, Pr(S = 1|X). We can see from figure 1e that under this selection mechanism, selection is independent of outcome Y and instrument Z after conditioning on X (i.e., pathways between S and Z, and S and Y are closed after conditioning on X). To calculate Pr(S = 1|X) we use Bayes theorem

First, let us calculate the conditional probability of selection for those participants who left school at age 15 (i.e., Pr(S = 1|X = 0)). We used information from the 2011 UK census to approximate information on all individuals invited to participate in the study (i.e., the selected and unselected). Prior to the introduction of the policy reform (i.e., Z = 0), September 1972, 33% of individuals left school at age 15, and so we set Pr(X = 0|Z = 0) = 0.33. Among the selected participants, 17.5% left school at age 15 prior to September 1972; that is, Pr(X = 0|S = 1, Z = 0) = 0.175. After the introduction of the policy reform, a small number of individuals did leave school at age 15. However, for the purposes of our illustrative example we have assumed from September 1972 onwards that all individuals left school aged 16 or older; that is, Pr(X = 0|Z = 1) = 0 and Pr(X = 0|S = 1, Z = 1) = 0. Therefore, Pr(X = 0) = Pr(X = 0|Z = 0)Pr(Z = 0) and Pr(X = 0|S = 1) = Pr(X = 0|S = 1, Z = 0)Pr(Z = 0). For the probability of selection, we know that 502, 644 out of 9.2 million invited participants attended the study clinic, and so Pr(S = 1) = 502644/9200000 = 0.055 (2 decimal places). Putting everything together we have:

Similarly, we can calculate the conditional probability of selection for those participants who left school age 16 or older (i.e., Pr(S = 1|X = 1)). From the UK census we have Pr(X = 1|Z = 0) = 1 - 0.33, and from the selected sample we have Pr(X = 1|S = 1, Z = 0) = 1 - 0.175. Given our assumption that post September 1972 all individuals left school aged 16 or older, then Pr(X = 1|Z = 1) = 1 and Pr(X = 1|S = 1, Z = 1) = 1. Since individuals could leave school age 16 or older before and after September 1972 then Pr(X = 1) = 0.67 × Pr(Z = 0) + Pr(Z = 1) = 1 - 0.33 × Pr(Z = 0), and Pr(X = 1|S = 1) = 0.825 × Pr(Z = 0) + Pr(Z = 1) = 1 - 0.175 × Pr(Z = 0). The probability Pr(Z = 0) is the proportion of the 9.2 million invited participants to which the introduction of the policy reform did not apply; that is, the proportion that turned 15 before September 1972. The recruitment period for the UK Biobank study was between 2006 and 2010, and so the mid-point was 2008. Participants unaffected by the policy reform had to have turned 51 years before September 2008. We approximate Pr(Z = 0) using population estimates for England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland supplied by the Office for National Statistics. Based on these population estimates for June 2008, among those aged between 40 to 70 years (UK Biobank’s sampling ages) the proportion over 50 was 0.58. So, we estimated that 58% of the invited UK Biobank participants had turned 51 years before September 2008 (i.e., Pr(Z = 0) = 0.58). Putting everything together we have:

Therefore, the selected participants who left school age 15 were weighted by 34.29 and the selected participants who left school age 16 or older were weighted by 12.37 (weights rounded to 2 decimal places). So, those participants suspected to be under-represented in the selected sample (i.e., left school age 15) contributed more to the analysis than those suspected to be over-represented in the selected sample (i.e. left school age 16 or older).
